												I used to play Guitar Hero with friends, got pretty decent at it, until I realised it was stupid spending that much time learning to play a piece of plastic. Soon after i got bored of it and stopped playing while thinking "it's sad you can't do the same but with an actual guitar so you'll learn to play it".So when I found out about Rocksmith, it sounded pretty much like what I had always hoped for a rythm game and I had to give it a shot, bought a boxed game version with the original cable (30€ on Ebay) and a (very crappy) 50€ second hand guitar from a brand even google never even heard of. Thing is, I'm freaking poor and couldn't afford spending 200€ on a decent guitar just to "give a shot" at Rocksmith and risk wasting it all if disapointed.So what do i think after a few weeks of trying? Well in short: HELL YEAH! If you're hesitating just go for it, you won't be disapointed. After years of unsuccessfull attempts to learn bass guitar, i can tell for sure i made a LOT more progress in only one week of Rocksmith than in 5 years of solo learning, and that's in both Bass and guitar (since a friend brought his bass to my place to play with me).I would'nt say for sure that Rocksmith will make you a guitarist/bassist, I think you'd still have to get a teacher at some point if that's really what you want, but if you want to learn the basics, improve your skills and check out how guitar work for you, Rocksmith will give you full satisfaction. You just skip the annoying, long, repetitive hard work part to go straight to "now I enjoy practicing" part. I only wish I had something better than that crappy guitar as it's becoming an obtacle to my progress, I'm currently trying to save up for that.My only advice: If you're buying a guitar for this game, don't go too cheap, you'll have nothing decent under about 200€ and it'll ruin a lot of the experience.Pros:-Excellent concept-Very entertaining-Very well done overall-Absolutely suitable to learn-Handle either guitar/ emulated bass (on guitar) / actual bass guitar-Allow 2 players to play together-Impressive real time adaptation to your skills and progress-Tyranics Mini-games to force you progress faster on a specific techniqueCons:-Menu is a little hard to navigate at first-The cable have some misses, I have to unplug/replug it every now and then, not dramatic but could be improved.-I miss a function to alternate players quickly, instead of changing profile after every songs.-We can't skip the noobish tutorial when creating a new profil, why would you do that? Just... why? Some player know how to press a string, they don't need an unskippable 15min lesson on it.-The songs database is a little short and not very diversed (pretty much only classic rock), and the songs to buy in the shop are quite f***ing expensive, 3€ each, not allowing poor players like me to enjoy many songs they really like.Conclusion:Very good game, such learning, much buy, wow.

												Here's how the game mostly works.  The game requires a special cable that allows you to plug your guitar into your computer.  So just downloading the game won't allow you to play it unless you have that special interface cable.  Once you plug in and tweak your options, the basic campaign will give you the simple "Rocksmith" experience.  When you first start, all of the songs are not yet "leveled up," so you only need to play just a few notes of the melody, and probably no chords at all.  But as you play each song again and again, the game figures out which sections of the song you're getting good at, and increases the difficulty, add more of the melody's original notes.  This goes on continually, for every song you play, making the game increasingly more challenging the more you play it.  After you have played each song and "leveled them up" to maximum, you'll basically be playing the song as it was recorded.As a "guitar instruction" method, I really think this has potential.  The early part of the game is simple enough that really ANYONE could play it, and the more you play, the more the game challenges you as a guitar player.  Each song as a few different arrangements, some focusing on lead, some on rhythm and chords.  The game is a harsh judge, so make sure you hit EVERY note, not just the ones that are easy to play!As some who already plays guitar, I found the game was most rewarding when I was selecting individual songs to play from the game's catalogue, without bothering with the campaign at all.  I sort of knew how to play Outshined already, but learning how to REALLY play it without cheating was a treat.  I pick a song I like, and practice all the parts of it individually until I can play them all, then I try to put them all together by playing the complete song on the maximum level.  Sometimes I can pull it off, depends on the song.So if you're already a guitar player, or you are really interested in learning to play, this game is definitely for you!  Tons of new songs to play as downloadable content.  But if you're a "gamer" who's not really much of a musician, even if you really liked Guitar Hero, I'd say this game is probably not your cup of tea.  It's more of a "musician's thing" than a game.The game also features support for basses, and an entire campaign just for bass players.  FINALLY, some respect!

												I have played guitar for many years and got this as a way to keep my chops up while not currently playing in a band. The verdict: it works! I recorded the same guitar part before and after about a dozen hours of playing the game's career mode and there was clearly an improvement in both my timing and phrasing--also the number of tries it took me to get a decent take when from like fifteen to one or two. I maybe would have seen the same result practicing along w/ a metronome but this seemed like more fun.The one major caveat for experienced players--esp. ones like myself who have never played anything like Guitar Hero--is that this is entirely unlike how most people typically learn to play songs. Normally, you learn part A, B, C and D or whatever and then the solos if you want and piece them together. This just throws sort of a fake book simplified version of the entire song at you all at once. As  you get better, it starts to fill in the notes until you are playing the actual guitar part. It's strange and sometimes frustrating but if you keep plugging away you will get through and eventually you learn to read the game's kinda 3D, color-coded tablature quite well and the process becomes quicker. My other complaints would be it can be a bit too lenient on timing and sometimes it lets you fudge chords. If you let the game's scoring dictate how you play, that can lead to bad habits. You need to show discipline on your own and play the parts correctly even if you can cheat a little and get a better score. Also, even using a relatively high end pro-sumer type soundcard (Focusrite Scarlett), there is a slight delay to the audio which you get used to but is enough to be annoying. It reminds me of playing on a digital guitar amp circa-2000, more of a feel thing but that matters. Overall though, this is a fun way to practice and I've found myself playing guitar more both with and without the game. I am just letting the game pick what songs to learn and am finding even the songs I don't like are actually fun to play. Also, like most people, practicing on my own, I tend to just practice the things I am good at and letting the game pick songs forces me out of my comfort zone. Definitely check this out if you are looking to improve your existing guitar skills.

												As a person that play an instrument since when he was 8, I would like to give an opinion about this "game".Overall, the presentation is nice, it is clean and has no frills; the options available are plenty; altho what the software is missing is a sort of guidance. There is a "suggested path", which takes you trough various venues; kinda mimicking what Rockband does: get a certain score in these events and you move on to different ones; but there is not a real career mode; everything is left to the player's will.I am not guitarist; I play guitar regularly for fun ,but far from being a person that can take a sheet and read it and play; I can do that with a keyboard, but I am not able to do so with a guitar; so I considered myself a good user which is part of the large portion of the audience for this game: from beginners to mildly good with guitar.When I started, I was immediately startled by the lack of whatsoever training; from what I read, this game teach you how to play...well, it doesn't. It is not different from getting a chord book and some sheet paper and start to try to play songs...there is no real teaching behind this product, as they want to market it.As a piano student for more than 15 years (I had to stop, no time, no space no will to continue, but I still play sometimes the elec keyboard); I was expecting to start from the easy things: like a good teacher would do: teach you the various notes, start with some exercises to familiarize, and then play simple songs as rhythm or second guitar. Nothing of this is happening here...if you start to follow what the game suggest, you will start to play real songs, which if you don't know the song too well, means you just go around looking at the fret, looking at the screen, back and forth, missing most of it. IF you do well for few phrases, the game increase the difficulty, which means that throw at you some hard part to play, making you feel frustrated (after the joy of being able to finally play something), and the game scale down again to a simplier structure.What is missing here is the basics; you should learn how to pluck each string; once that you do it on one chord, the game should challenge you to pluck more strings, so you get the green, purple, orange colors, besides the initial red and yellow strings that seems to be used at easy level most of the time.Then the game should teach you how to move your hand to play clean notes with one finger; and once you are good at that, should teach you the various scale, so you can play notes without even move your hand from a specific position. Done that, the game should teach you chords, and how to transpose them on the fretboard, doing variations.I mean, that's boring stuff, and I am aware of that; but this gives you the skills and muscle memory to then learn what to play when you play a real song! I had to exercise on my own doing these things, before I was able to enjoy this program...if they market it as learning game; they may want to use it as real learning tool, and not simply force you to have to do a bunch of stuff for the sake of it, until you finally did it so many times, that your brain learned it.This is not how you learn; at least not as most people do. You learn with practice, but you need the basics first.I bring as example, Rockband and how it teach the drum: in that case it works because you have limited variations (you have just 6 pads plus the pedal), and in the beginning, the song are arranged in a very simple way, making you feel that you got it, before you move to the next difficulty level; while here I felt totally lost when I started to play few songs, right after buying the game. It may be me, but I really dislike this "method" used with this software: is not making me play the same song over  and over again that you teach me.If they were planning to teach each song, they would start with some exercises on the specific chords of each song; specific riff and such (which seems to be present in Rocksmith 2, I have that game too and it is leaps and bounds better than the first one); while here you have to go in the library, learn some chords; then go to the lessons and follow them, then back to some challenges to increase your flexibility and speed and then you go back to the song....all is left to the player, which is the best and worst feature of this software.Song-wise; I basically dislike 80% of them; ironically the best songs are the small ones that you play while performing the various skill challenges, written by the developers. Maybe is just my taste, but I see a lack of 80% of what made rock popular....they saved these songs for the DLC and the second game probably.OVerall; the game to me is a solid 6 out of 10; entertaining once you know the songs, and the various lessons and skill challenge are a good way to keep you entertained and trained; but for a total newbie that start today with a guitar, it feels more like a chore than a fun thing (unless he/she is totally determined to learn guitar and love and know most of the songs).The majority seems to like it, guess you can't make everyone happy. As suggestion, skip this and buy directly Rocksmith 2 (or wait for the 3rd, which hopefully resolve the last issues of this product).

												I'd always laughed at THOSE games. You know the ones. Guitar Hero, DJ Hero, Triangle Hero, Tamborine Hero, Kazoo Quest, etc etc. However a year ago I finally got up to date on the Donkey Kong rhythm platform game on the Gamecube. In this, you use bongos to control attacks, movement and jumping.. you really feel like a monkey, bashing away at those bongos.But anyway, that got me thinking how cool ACTUAL music is as a control/input/interface method for gaming. Then, I found out about this.Unlike those lame Flute Quest Hero games, in this, you don't have a plastic flute or french horn or scratch turntable, but rather the actual musical equivalent. For this game, it is focused so far on guitar and bass. I am using a 7 string guitar, in a different  tuning to the game. My guitar was set up for this drop F tuning, so I was worried at first it might not like my guitar.. well, it wasn't an issue. There are stickers provided in the box that allow you to set the numbers of your frets via stickers on your guitar, so for me that was perfect, moving the frets up 2 spaces and ignoring my 7th/lowest string, I can play the game fine. Harmonics are a little tricky tho, but can always tune up for those tracks/parts..In its essence, this is the best way to learn guitar. The best way for guitarists of any skill level to play along with other people's tunes, as well as for experienced guitarists to have a program with which to assess and further develop your existing skills. The DLCs are great, a little bit of metal is available - Pantera, Lamb Of God and some oldies like Megadeath.. some indie rock like Pixies, but mostly this is about rock, new and classic. There is a multiplayer aspect, but it's only local and you need to get two cables for it.. wondering if latency would increase due to extra guitar or bass input..Also if you want to practice bass on a guitar, it has an octave pedal to 'emulate' bass on guitar. It's a pity there is no online multiplayer, but there is leaderboard scoring.Not to mention there is an updated version RS2014 coming out in rOcktober, with support for different tunings (only found standard and drop D so far in the game). There's a lot that could come to this game and a lot that is already in there so it's hard to describe everything. I dream of one day there being mod support for this title, or plugin/addon support by community producers. At the moment however there is a large range of DLC tunes you can purchase for $3.50 USD (in my region) each.. not a bad price to own a song, but also to have the tablature and a program to help you learn it :)The latency is a bit of an issue at first, but once fiddling with the ini or game settings, you can get something reasonable.. seems to be somewhere around 30-200ms range depending on settings, but it can be worse if you don't follow the set up guides or have a cruddy PCI/PCI-E soundcard or a slow computer.There's a lot to recommend about this game - support it and throw away any other music games you have that involve plastic. Why learn how to play a peace of plastic when you can play the real thing..While it is harder to get into it, if you don't have an electric guitar or bass (obviously this is required for the game, but it doesn't mention it on the system requirements on the back, LOL!) it might be a bit of cost to buy one to play this.. but still, I think I would have learnt A LOT quicker when I started playing guitar 15 years ago, if I had've had this tool at my disposal then. The marketing is true - it IS the quickest and easiest way to learn guitar, I fully endorse that. However if you are not sure guitar is for you, also if you are younger or have softer hands/skin, it might be worth starting out on a cheap nylon string acoustic before moving to steel string electric..

												If you have an electric guitar laying around and wouldn't mind learning how to play, this is a great way to start. I've been teaching myself for about five years now and purchased Rocksmith on the grounds of learning some songs I have a hard time finding tabs for online. Though I wanted to jump to the hardest difficulty to get a 100% accurate tab instead of every other note in a song, the game insists on taking it easy and adding difficulty as you play along and presumably get better. I'm a bit stubborn so I was a little unsure about this at first- but this is how improvements are made. You PRACTICE. So as I played, I noticed songs gradually start adding more notes as opposed to the simple starting fragments. This system works great. There's also tons of little games to sharpen certain skills. The best feature in my book, strangely enough, became the settings for all the amps. As the owner of an amp with just-alright sound settings, having a ton of new sounds and effects to work with was awesome. I have actually found myself: plugging the guitar into my computer to fire up the game, selecting an in-game amp setting, then plugging my headphone jack into the aux. on my amp, and using Rocksmith as my new amp at the volume of my real amp. Rocksmith is a valuable asset for someone who already plays guitar as well as those interested in giving it a go. Give it a try!

												Finally, a game comes along that has the potential to actually turn you into a rockstar. Well, maybe not literally, but Rocksmith can help you really learn songs. No more mashing colored buttons rhythmically on cheap toy controllers, because Rocksmith lets you use REAL GUITARS and BASSES to play along and learn songs. It reads the output of your instrument, so it knows if your playing the right notes or not at the right timing (provided you adjusted your latency properly).This is incredible for noobs -- beginners just starting out who want to learn a few popular songs, because Rocksmith is less of a game and more of a gamified teaching tool. It tracks your progress, adapting to your apparent skill level mid song, so you'll see a few note fly on the screen at first, but if you play more notes, Rocksmith doesn't punish you, but instead decides to display more and more notes until the "real" guitar/bassline is finally revealed. Essentially, the game rewards you for being a better musician, the way it should be.There are plenty of modes that teach techniques like string bending, double stops, hammer ons/pull offs, muting -- mainly through tutorials and games. These techniques are also used in songs, so they become as practical as they are entertaining.Overall I'd have to say that Rocksmith is the best thing for beginners to learn songs beyond crappy online tabs, paying for lessons, books, "hot licks" DVDs or investing in software like Transcribe (which is excellent and I recommend to anybody remotely serious about learning music) to slow down tunes and learn piece by piece.

Posted: July 17, 2013
												Guitar Hero Who? Man, this game blows that out of the water. Want to really learn how to play guitar? This is the real deal. And for $10...what a steal! You still have to have a real guitar and pick and you have to get the USB cable to plug into your guitar...but man! what a great learning tool.I already knew some chords and songs, so picking this up didn't have a huge learning curve. But if you've never picked up a guitar before, this might be a bit of a challenge. But the payoff is, you will learn how to really play the songs in the game and real chords and progressions that you can use to train your fingers to play many other songs.The real beauty of this game though come in 2 forms. The first, is that it turns your computer into an amp. As you progress through the game, you earn amps, guitars, and effects pedals. Then, when you just want to practice outside of the journey or mini-games, you have multiple effects and amps to tweak your sound.The second, and most important, is that this game adjust the difficulty in REAL TIME! It is awesome. It senses, mid-song, if you are struggling, and then tones down the difficulty. And, if you are doing well, it slowly increases the difficulty while you are in the middle of playing. If it senses that it bumped up the difficulty too much, it takes it down a notch. Watching this happen mid-song makes what could be a frustrating experience into a very satisfying one. Some songs have easier riffs than others, and to be rewarded for your effort is awesome.Pick this game up and then go look at the library for some DLC. I have added 2 songs to my list of songs from the DLC, and it makes the game that more fun to be able to play along with songs I really enjoy.

Posted: January 7, 2013
												This is Guitar Hero with an actual guitar, or bass, if you so choose!I was definitely skeptical about this, as it seemed like a great idea, but I wasn't sure if Rocksmith could deliver exactly what it said it could in a quality program worth the high price. To my surprise, it did end up being worth every penny.The Rocksmith Real-tone cable (which must be purchased seperately) actually works amazingly well, and when you're not playing in career mode or just playing random songs, you can just go into "Amp mode" and jam out, which contains an insane amount of custimization for sounds and tones etc. and more can be unlocked and purchased.I really thought this was going to be a hard game, but it starts you off slow and depending on how well you do, difficulty is altered, allowing you to play more notes to a song until by the end, if you're doing well enough, you are playing the entire thing.The game walks you through every step, from the very beginning, and even though some parts here are slow for experienced players looking to jump right into the game, it's definitely going to be very useful for beginners. When you get to more difficult songs that require chords, tremolos, hammer-ons, you name it, there are tutorials and mini games based on playing those notes that will appear, teaching you how to perform them while having fun at the same time. Even when you do lose, you just want to keep going because every time you get a little better, and after mastering any of these, you truly feel like you have become a better player.There is an in-game guitar tuner which works better then any tuner I have ever even used in real life. Before every song, you hit each string, and it lets you know if you're in tune. If you're not, the tuner pops up, and tells you how to adjust. Although this may sound annoying, it usually only takes 3 seconds if nothing has to be tuned, and ends up being extremely useful, and practical, regarding tune-age upkeep.What you are learning here are REAL songs, that you can practice in the game, and then go play later.In only 24 hours I have learned over a dozen songs, and although I can't play them all flawlessly or in their entirety, some of them I've gotten pretty damn close, and eventually with practice, you can nail any song. You literally start to impress yourself with what you have learned in such a short time. I really didn't think it would ever even be possible to learn popular songs without teachers or tablature, it takes up too much time and is frustrating, so I have mostly only ever played by ear or wrote my own material in the few years that I've been playing, but this game solves those issues and proves me wrong.I even reccomend this to people who are still pretty new to guitar. It's fun, and actually makes you WANT to learn, because you see yourself progressively getting better. It's faster and much more simple then using tabs, the only thing is you only have so many songs to choose from.Sincerely impressed by the quality of this game/program/purchase.  They took a great idea, put it together, achieved, and then delivered if not the best possible outcome, pretty damn close to it.

Posted: August 6, 2015
												The following is my review in pseudo FAQ format. Enjoy! :)Why did I buy Rocksmith?I bought this as a way to learn to play an electric guitar - something that I (and I suspect many others) have wanted to do since childhood but never really had the right tuition or couldn't quite follow along with a book/video. Mainly because you can't necessarily trust an instructor to be able to tell if you're hitting the right notes/chords and a book/video may assume a skill level or familiarity that you, as the learner, just do not possess.Also, as per usual, it was in a sale and it's taken me at least a year to get around to buying a Real Tone cable once the price had come down in price to £20 on Amazon.Do you actually learn how to play a guitar?Yes. Yes you do.  You start with simple single note arrangements of songs, leading to complex single note arrangements and then on to a combination of single notes and chords before going to full chords.  The speed at which you do this depends on what Rocksmith thinks is best for you in terms of your actual ability, with arrangements being made simpler or harder (or truer to the actual song being played if you prefer).  You can also practice specific chords of a chosen song, any part of a song, different arrangements, or change songs in your "setlist" to ones you're more familiar with and/or genres you prefer.Starting with single notes, you are also memorising your guitar's fretboard and how far to move your fingers without even counting the frets as you go.  As you progress further, Rocksmith will introduce new elements such as sliding from one fret to another - both as part of the song you're playing and to further cement fret positions in your mind.  Even after a few days to the end of your first week of playing, you'll find yourself being able to play songs with far fewer mistakes (perhaps even perfectly, as of course everyone learns at different speeds).  Certainly, you would have started developing those all important calluses!Okay, I get that Rocksmith is a learning tool - but what's Rocksmith like as a game?As a game, Rocksmith is far more entertaining than say Guitar Hero/Rock Band in that you're genuinely playing along with a real guitar (that needn't cost the same as a Guitar Hero/Rock Band accessory), and is always just challenging enough in difficulty and the side games provide a welcome relief to learning songs and using a real guitar as an alternative controller whilst still being educational.  The Rocksmith Points that you get for completing songs and side games all add up to your resulting score and is a good objective metric of your progress/ability.Speaking of side games, these are unlocked as you progress so that you're never in a position where you are in way over your head.  For example, the first game unlocked is the Duck Shoot where you play single notes on the 6th string in particular fret positions to shoot the ducks, simple enough. But from there as you progress, you'll unlock the scales mini game and so on, providing an incentive to carry on and is yet another way of letting you know how far you've come from starting out.Additionally, there is a multiplayer mode and it's up to you and those you're playing with if you want to be competitive or use it to encourage as a group to all learn a skill.What's the song selection like?Like a higher priced budget collection in that all the songs are well known and like all budget collections, you'll be a fan of some more than others (perhaps by a great margin).  For example: if you want popular 50s rock artists like Chuck Berry and Bill Haley? You're out of luck. There aren't any TV/Film themes either (which are almost traditional to learn) or rock instrumentals such as FBI by The Shadows.If you like Nirvana, Snow Patrol, The Red Hot Chilli Peppers and the like (generally popular rock from the late 80s onwards) then you'll be escstatic and perhaps disappointed your favourite song wasn't included, which is small beer when compared to those of us who prefer 1950s-1970s rock given that we get 8 songs (three of these being by The Rolling Stones - with none of them being Paint It Black! Have to upgrade to Rocksmith 2014 to get that one) out of a total 57 that come with the base game (6 are unlocked as you play, all of which are from 2011).  For the sake of completion, two of the songs from 1988 onwards are Run Back To Your Side by Eric Clapton (2010) and Jarvis Cocker (formerly of Pulp fame) represented with one of his solo efforts "Angela" (2009).  For Clapton and Pulp fans (of which I'm neither), this is something of a raw deal given the  respective back catalogues.Well what about the DLC are my/your tastes catered to there?Yes and no. If you live in the US? You'll be fine, all the DLC is available to you. In the EU, not so much. I'd like to be able to buy "Roadhouse Blues" by The Doors along with packs only available in the US region (the orchestral/classical selections should be royalty free by now the world over, so why only a US release Ubisoft?).My conclusionRocksmith is a good learning tool to practice to your preferred songs (where available) and if you prefer mid-80s onwards, you're very much catered for.  I'd also recommend Rocksmith as a solid stepping stone to give you a head start when it comes to training DVDs and books, given that you'll have at least a working knowledge of playing a guitar.I'd also advise going in with the mentality of treating songs by artists you're not fond of (or even heard of depending on your tastes) as a level to be mastered.  It works, but songs you actually enjoy may help you better - each to their own in that regard!Have fun though, learn, and impress yourself if no one else that you've learned a new skill!

												The following is my review in pseudo FAQ format. Enjoy! :)Why did I buy Rocksmith?I bought this as a way to learn to play an electric guitar - something that I (and I suspect many others) have wanted to do since childhood but never really had the right tuition or couldn't quite follow along with a book/video. Mainly because you can't necessarily trust an instructor to be able to tell if you're hitting the right notes/chords and a book/video may assume a skill level or familiarity that you, as the learner, just do not possess.Also, as per usual, it was in a sale and it's taken me at least a year to get around to buying a Real Tone cable once the price had come down in price to £20 on Amazon.Do you actually learn how to play a guitar?Yes. Yes you do.  You start with simple single note arrangements of songs, leading to complex single note arrangements and then on to a combination of single notes and chords before going to full chords.  The speed at which you do this depends on what Rocksmith thinks is best for you in terms of your actual ability, with arrangements being made simpler or harder (or truer to the actual song being played if you prefer).  You can also practice specific chords of a chosen song, any part of a song, different arrangements, or change songs in your "setlist" to ones you're more familiar with and/or genres you prefer.Starting with single notes, you are also memorising your guitar's fretboard and how far to move your fingers without even counting the frets as you go.  As you progress further, Rocksmith will introduce new elements such as sliding from one fret to another - both as part of the song you're playing and to further cement fret positions in your mind.  Even after a few days to the end of your first week of playing, you'll find yourself being able to play songs with far fewer mistakes (perhaps even perfectly, as of course everyone learns at different speeds).  Certainly, you would have started developing those all important calluses!Okay, I get that Rocksmith is a learning tool - but what's Rocksmith like as a game?As a game, Rocksmith is far more entertaining than say Guitar Hero/Rock Band in that you're genuinely playing along with a real guitar (that needn't cost the same as a Guitar Hero/Rock Band accessory), and is always just challenging enough in difficulty and the side games provide a welcome relief to learning songs and using a real guitar as an alternative controller whilst still being educational.  The Rocksmith Points that you get for completing songs and side games all add up to your resulting score and is a good objective metric of your progress/ability.Speaking of side games, these are unlocked as you progress so that you're never in a position where you are in way over your head.  For example, the first game unlocked is the Duck Shoot where you play single notes on the 6th string in particular fret positions to shoot the ducks, simple enough. But from there as you progress, you'll unlock the scales mini game and so on, providing an incentive to carry on and is yet another way of letting you know how far you've come from starting out.Additionally, there is a multiplayer mode and it's up to you and those you're playing with if you want to be competitive or use it to encourage as a group to all learn a skill.What's the song selection like?Like a higher priced budget collection in that all the songs are well known and like all budget collections, you'll be a fan of some more than others (perhaps by a great margin).  For example: if you want popular 50s rock artists like Chuck Berry and Bill Haley? You're out of luck. There aren't any TV/Film themes either (which are almost traditional to learn) or rock instrumentals such as FBI by The Shadows.If you like Nirvana, Snow Patrol, The Red Hot Chilli Peppers and the like (generally popular rock from the late 80s onwards) then you'll be escstatic and perhaps disappointed your favourite song wasn't included, which is small beer when compared to those of us who prefer 1950s-1970s rock given that we get 8 songs (three of these being by The Rolling Stones - with none of them being Paint It Black! Have to upgrade to Rocksmith 2014 to get that one) out of a total 57 that come with the base game (6 are unlocked as you play, all of which are from 2011).  For the sake of completion, two of the songs from 1988 onwards are Run Back To Your Side by Eric Clapton (2010) and Jarvis Cocker (formerly of Pulp fame) represented with one of his solo efforts "Angela" (2009).  For Clapton and Pulp fans (of which I'm neither), this is something of a raw deal given the  respective back catalogues.Well what about the DLC are my/your tastes catered to there?Yes and no. If you live in the US? You'll be fine, all the DLC is available to you. In the EU, not so much. I'd like to be able to buy "Roadhouse Blues" by The Doors along with packs only available in the US region (the orchestral/classical selections should be royalty free by now the world over, so why only a US release Ubisoft?).My conclusionRocksmith is a good learning tool to practice to your preferred songs (where available) and if you prefer mid-80s onwards, you're very much catered for.  I'd also recommend Rocksmith as a solid stepping stone to give you a head start when it comes to training DVDs and books, given that you'll have at least a working knowledge of playing a guitar.I'd also advise going in with the mentality of treating songs by artists you're not fond of (or even heard of depending on your tastes) as a level to be mastered.  It works, but songs you actually enjoy may help you better - each to their own in that regard!Have fun though, learn, and impress yourself if no one else that you've learned a new skill!

Its too bad some advanced (shredding) techniques are not available (hopefully there's gonna be an expansion for intermediate guitarists) and this is reflected by the setlist, not a lot of really fast metal, you're gonna have to get that from the DLCs. Even though there are some songs in the setlist I could care less for (they're there mainly to appeal to more pop-oriented people), all in all there's a solid collection of tracks.Because the techniques in the game are nothing new to me, I mainly use it to practice my skills on bass, since my fingerpicking can be a little more tight :)The game does not really support multiplayer as much as Guitar Hero. You can play gigs with your friends of course, switching the guitar every song, provided they have some guitar skills of their own. The learning curve of playing real guitar is still steaper than playing Guitar Hero, although the game supports a dynamic difficulty system, making it a little more accessible (but annoying if you want to really learn the proper way of playing a song, you're gonna have to unlock a master mode first). The game has some mini (arcade) games that do not require much skill and I guess those can provide for some multiplayer.The best thing about it, is that it makes you want to keep on playing and practicing and this is a vital aspect of trying to learn to play any instrument really, so its really more recommendable to novice guitarists, who want to learn to play, but so far really can't seem to put the time and effort in.The game comes with a cable for plugging your guitar into your PC, so its better to get a physical copy from a story with a cable included than just a digital download, because you can't play this game without that cable (and a guitar to plug in to it).
